import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
states=pd.read_csv('states_all.csv')
states.head()

#2 draw a line
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

outputs.name: stdout
text: Total expenditure of California: [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x12e082430>] None

outputs.name: stdout
text: Total revenue of California: [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x12a696220>] None

source:
print('Total revenue of California:',plt.plot(s2['YEAR'],s2['TOTAL_REVENUE']),plt.show())
#we can see that around 2008, total revenue is dropped probably due to the Global Financial Crisis.
#before that, we can also observe that increasing revenues. This is also probably because of excessive money arising from
 the expansionary monetary policies of FED.
    #In 1994, Mexican Tequila Crisis also affected US market, therefore the revenues of California.

#3 successful at math or reading
s2=states[['STATE','AVG_MATH_4_SCORE', 'AVG_MATH_8_SCORE',
       'AVG_READING_4_SCORE', 'AVG_READING_8_SCORE']]
s3=s2[s2['STATE']=='CALIFORNIA']
s3.head()

source:
print('mean of average Reading Grades:',(208.230769+255.0)/2 )
print('mean of average math Grades:',(227.909091+269.166667)/2 )
#we can conclude that they are better at math

#4
plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))
plt.subplot(1,4,1)
plt.hist(s3['AVG_MATH_4_SCORE'].dropna())
plt.title('CaliforniaAVG_MATH_4_SCORE')
plt.subplot(1,4,2)
plt.hist(s3['AVG_MATH_8_SCORE'].dropna())
plt.title('CaliforniaAVG_MATH_8_SCORE')
plt.subplot(1,4,3)
plt.hist(s3['AVG_READING_4_SCORE'].dropna())
plt.title('CaliforniaAVG_READING_4_SCORE')
plt.subplot(1,4,4)
plt.hist(s3['AVG_READING_8_SCORE'].dropna())
plt.title('CaliforniaAVG_READING_8_SCORE')
plt.show()
#we see that they are non-normal distributions.
